title: As Frozen Land Burns, Siberia Fears: ‘If We Don’t Have the Forest, We Don’t Have Life’
description: Northeastern Siberia is a place where people take Arctic temperatures in stride. But 100-degree days are another matter entirely.
content: MAGARAS, Russia — The call for help lit up villagers’ phones at 7:42 on a muggy and painfully smoky evening on Siberia’s fast-warming permafrost expanse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Sergey Ponomarev
title: Hospital Fires Outrage Iraqis, but They See Little Hope for Change
description: Two catastrophic fires in coronavirus wards are symptoms of the mismanagement and corruption that have left millions of Iraqis without proper health care, reliable electricity or clean water.
content: NASIRIYA, Iraq — The provincial civil defense chief, Brig. Gen. Salah Jabar, had warned for months about the problems in local hospitals before a fire in a coronavirus ward in this southern city killed at least 60 people this week. He flagged the flammable construction materials, a lack of fire detectors and improperly stored oxygen canisters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Britain’s health secretary, Sajid Javid, tests positive for the coronavirus.
description: He announced the results of a rapid test in a video posted on Twitter, and said he was isolating while awaiting confirmation with a P.C.R. test.
content: Sajid Javid, Britain’s new health secretary, said on Saturday in a short video on Twitter that he had tested positive for the coronavirus, only two days before almost all of the country’s virus-related restrictions were set to be lifted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meryl Davids Landau
title: What Do Police Know About Teenagers? Not Enough.
description: An Indiana county has instructed every cop on how teens differ developmentally. Unnecessary arrests have plummeted as a result.
content: The day Brian Lowe attended a training session for police officers on understanding the minds of teenagers, he knew his job would never be the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: 3 Texas Democrats who fled their state to stall a voting bill test positive in Washington.
description: The Texas House Democratic Caucus did not name the three lawmakers, but said they were all fully vaccinated.
content: Three of the nearly 60 Texas Democrats who fled Texas this week in an effort to prevent the passage of a restrictive new voting law have tested positive for the coronavirus in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: They Go Around in Circles
description: The road to completion in a Ryan McCarty puzzle is rarely a straight line .
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid reminds me of yesterday’s themeless, rotated and with its middle filled in. I like the second bit and I like to think that the solving thrill of those six long-crossing entries in the center, four of them debuts, is the kind of thing that Saturday solvers can have to themselves, even though I know it’s not true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: ‘A Special Sadness’: Floods Bring Death to a German Care Home
description: Given no warning and trapped by fast-rising waters, 12 disabled residents of a care home drowned before aid could arrive, shaking Germans everywhere.
content: SINZIG, Germany — If the calamitous floods that have hit Germany have an emotional center, it is in Sinzig, a small town between the Rhine and Ahr rivers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: Why People Are So Awful Online
description: On social media, we are all hammers seeking nails.
content: When I joined Twitter 14 years ago, I was living in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula, attending graduate school. I lived in a town of around 4,000 people, with few Black people or other people of color, not many queer people and not many writers. Online is where I found a community beyond my graduate school peers. I followed and met other emerging writers, many of whom remain my truest friends. I got to share opinions, join in on memes, celebrate people’s personal joys, process the news with others and partake in the collective effervescence of watching awards shows with thousands of strangers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fira Abdurachman, Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
title: The Pandemic Has a New Epicenter: Indonesia
description: The suffering that ravaged places like India and Brazil — with deaths soaring, hospitals overwhelmed and oxygen running out — has reached Southeast Asia.
content: BEKASI, Indonesia — By the thousands, they sleep in hallways, tents and cars, gasping for air as they wait for beds in overcrowded hospitals that may not have oxygen to give them. Others see hospitals as hopeless, even dangerous, and take their chances at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Mark Mazzetti
title: Israeli Companies Aided Saudi Spying Despite Khashoggi Killing
description: Ignoring concerns that Saudi Arabia was abusing Israeli spyware to crush dissent at home and abroad, Israel encouraged its companies to work with the kingdom.
content: TEL AVIV — Israel secretly authorized a group of cyber-surveillance firms to work for the government of Saudi Arabia despite international condemnation of the kingdom’s abuse of surveillance software to crush dissent, even after the Saudi killing of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi, government officials and others familiar with the contracts said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Conservatives Can Reshape Education
description: The right needs to create institutions, not just restrict what the ones we have can teach.
content: After spending a few columns exploring current debates about history and race and education, I intended to step back and write about why the conservative effort to use state legislation to block new progressive educational theories is likely to ultimately fail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: In Undervaccinated Arkansas, Covid Upends Life All Over Again
description: While much of the nation tiptoes toward normalcy, the coronavirus is again swamping hospitals in places like Mountain Home, in a rural county where fewer than one-third of residents are vaccinated.
content: MOUNTAIN HOME, Ark. — When the boat factory in this leafy Ozark Mountains city offered free coronavirus vaccinations this spring, Susan Johnson, 62, a receptionist there, declined the offer, figuring she was protected as long as she never left her house without a mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Vecsey
title: Greetings From a Dormant Newsroom
description: My colleagues are returning. Slowly. In the meantime, our office remains a ghostly work space.
content: It’s quiet. Too quiet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan, Ron DePasquale and Lauren McCarthy
title: Many travelers to England may skip quarantine as of Monday, but not those from France, where Beta is present.
description: Most virus-related restrictions in England will be lifted on “freedom day,” but travelers arriving from France must quarantine for five to 10 days, regardless of vaccination status.
content: British medical officials announced on Friday that fully vaccinated travelers arriving in England from France must continue to quarantine because of the threat posed by the Beta variant, though vaccinated travelers from other European nations on Britain’s medium-risk amber list will no longer have to quarantine as of Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Los Angeles County’s sheriff declines to enforce the mask mandate about to resume.
description: Sheriff Alex Villanueva has repeatedly declined to enforce Covid restrictions, including a statewide stay-at-home order last winter.
content: A new requirement that masks be worn indoors in Los Angeles County goes into effect Saturday night. But the local sheriff says he won’t enforce the mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Slip Sliding Away From History
description: Not so fast, you enablers scurrying for the exits!
content: WASHINGTON — It is a hoary tradition: Outfox history, if you can.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson, Ben Sisario and Robin Pogrebin
title: As New York Reopens, It Looks for Culture to Lead the Way
description: The arts  —  Broadway, nightclubs, museums, concert halls — are coming back to life after the shutdown. Getting it right will be vital to the city’s comeback.
content: Broadway is planning to start performances of at least three dozen shows before the end of the year, but producers do not know if there will be enough tourists — who typically make up two-thirds of the audience — to support all of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi and Mike Ives
title: 6-Year-Old Girl in Washington Is Fatally Shot While Riding Scooter
description: The shooting in the nation’s capital on Friday night also left five adults wounded, according to the police, who pleaded with the public for help.
content: WASHINGTON — A 6-year-old girl was killed and five adults were wounded in a late-night shooting on Friday, horrifying residents of the neighborhood and frustrating investigators who pleaded with the public to help them catch those responsible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Investors Bet on Foie Gras Grown From Cells in a Lab
description: Gourmey, a start-up based in Paris, received an additional $10 million in seed funding this week. The company hopes to find a market in the United States amid growing concerns about animal cruelty.
content: Can foie gras grown in a lab taste just as decadent and creamy as that made from farm-raised ducks or geese?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Back to Militias, the Chaotic Afghan Way of War
description: Concerned by the Taliban’s offensive, regional power brokers are again recruiting and arming volunteer militias. But some fear the quick fix will lead to a wider breakdown.
content: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan—Omid Wahidi was born after the United States invaded Afghanistan in 2001. His childhood, for the most part, was peaceful. His family farmed eggplant, tomato and okra in the country’s north. He remembers foreign troops throwing books to him as he walked out of school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: How to Have a Fun, Multigenerational Family Vacation
description: Sometimes a trip with small children means the same chores in a different place. Here’s advice on how to make it a vacation.
content: Feeling released after a terrible year, this summer many families are hitting the road or taking to the skies with three or more generations, together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon concoct a culinary challenge.
content: ACROSTIC — This is a poster child of an acrostic, not terribly slow going, full of grace notes in the clues, resulting in a quirky and surprising passage.  I can sense the fun Team Emily Cox/Henry Rathvon must have had putting it all together for us, and (as always) it’s much appreciated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: A Free-Throw Expert’s Advice for Giannis: Just Shoot It
description: Giannis Antetokounmpo, the Milwaukee Bucks star, has frustrated fans and opponents with his drawn-out free-throw routine that often ends with a miss.
content: Philip Flory, a college basketball player from Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., is a huge fan of the Milwaukee Bucks. He is rooting for them in the N.B.A. finals against the Phoenix Suns, though Flory has found himself cringing whenever Giannis Antetokounmpo, the Bucks’ do-everything forward and one of his favorite players, tries to do one of the few things that make him look vulnerable: shoot free throws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: A Reporter’s Fight to Expose Epstein’s Crimes — and Earn a Living
description: Julie Brown's "Perversion of Justice" is a reminder of how much local news matters.
content: At a news conference after Jeffrey Epstein’s 2019 sex trafficking indictment, a reporter asked Geoffrey Berman, then the U.S. attorney in Manhattan, if new information had prompted his office’s inquiry. The F.B.I., after all, had investigated Epstein’s sexual predation more than a decade earlier, and the crimes in the 2019 indictment took place between 2002 and 2005. Berman revealed little about what went on inside his office, but said that his team was helped by “some excellent investigative journalism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: British Open Heads for Furious Finish With Stars Tight at the Top
description: Louis Oosthuizen, Collin Morikawa and Jordan Spieth are battling one another — and their nerves — with just a few strokes separating them atop the leaderboard.
content: SANDWICH, England — Collin Morikawa and Jordan Spieth had much in common as the third round of the British Open ended on Saturday in the sort of gentle breezes and golden, early evening light more associated with Augusta National than the English seaside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Biden’s Made Progress on Climate, Even if Activists Can’t See It
description: The president’s monumental environmental gambit.
content: It is hard to overstate the joy of the environmental community when Joe Biden ascended to the White House. In place of a man who called climate change a hoax, it got someone who saw global warming for the grave threat it is, and who spoke, at his inaugural, of the world’s duty to respond to “a cry for survival” that “comes from the planet itself.” It got someone who saw government regulations not as “job killers” but as appropriate levers to achieve cleaner air and water. It got someone who viewed the public lands not as a resource to be exploited by commercial interests but as nature’s gift to future generations. A worthy custodian, in short, to the environmental ethic of Teddy Roosevelt, Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton. And someone who would spend trillions to make it all happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Positive coronavirus tests halt the production of ‘Bridgerton’ in the U.K. twice in three days.
description: On Saturday, a spokeswoman for Netflix declined to say whether the test that caused the second halt was that of a cast member or a crew member.
content: Amid a rapidly spiking Delta-driven surge of coronavirus cases in Britain, the second season of the Netflix series “Bridgerton” halted filming for the second time in three days, after someone involved with the production tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Liz Alderman
title: As Lebanon Collapses, the Man With an Iron Grip on Its Finances Faces Questions
description: People can’t get their money from banks, the currency has crashed and Riad Salameh’s reign at the central bank is facing allegations of fraud.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For decades, Riad Salameh, Lebanon’s central bank chief, was lauded at home and abroad as a financial wizard who kept the economy running and the currency stable despite wars, assassinations and frequent political turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Where Are the Fans for Israel’s National Baseball Team? In New York.
description: The Tokyo-bound Israeli national baseball team has more supporters in New York than in its home country.
content: Shortly before the start of a recent exhibition game, the members of Israel’s national baseball team assembled along the third base line at Maimonides Field in Coney Island and replaced their baseball caps with yarmulkes in preparation for the singing of the Israeli national anthem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Dig In
description: Belly up to Jesse Goldberg’s delectable Sunday debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s quotation theme is a treat, the return of a great character for longtime solvers, an introduction for newbies. Jesse Goldberg is a software engineer in San Francisco who has come up with an online crossword building tool called “Crosserville” that I predict will be cited in future constructors’ notes, so if you ever wonder if you’ve got it in you, “it” might only be that one click away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Keith McNally Stirs the Pot
description: For decades the powerful restaurateur knew exactly how to keep people coming back to his downtown spots. Has he figured out a new formula?
content: One of the luckiest things that can happen to a restaurant is for it to remain open long enough to become a place that famous people used to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sebastian Modak
title: From Lin-Manuel to Pollan to St. Aubyn: Audiobooks for Every Attention Span
description: Fiction and nonfiction for the busiest, most distracted of listeners.
content: One of the best things about audiobooks is how conducive they are to multitasking. You can learn something new or be entertained while sorting the laundry, walking the dog, waiting for a flight. But that same versatility — audiobooks’ ability to retreat into the background of everyday life — can also be their downfall. Focus too much on what you are doing at the same time as listening and you can miss key plot twists, or a particularly funny turn of phrase. Before you know it, you are adrift, unable to process what you’re hearing, unsure of when exactly you started spacing out. All that is to say: Audiobook multitasking takes practice. Here are three new audiobooks that respectively hit the beginner, intermediate and advanced levels of semi-distracted listening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: In Texas, Top Two Republicans Steer Ship of State Hard to the Right
description: Different in style and background, Gov. Greg Abbott and Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick have come together, for different reasons, to push an uncompromising conservative agenda.
content: One is a former State Supreme Court justice who acts with a lawyer’s caution; the other a Trumpist firebrand who began his political career in the world of conservative talk radio. They have sparred at times, most recently this winter over the deadly failure of their state’s electrical grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: How Republican Vaccine Opposition Got to This Point
description: In recent months, Republican skepticism of Covid vaccines and their rollout has grown louder: One recent poll found that 47 percent said they weren’t likely to get vaccinated.
content: After Sherri Tenpenny, a Cleveland-area doctor, falsely suggested during a hearing last month in the Ohio House of Representatives that Covid vaccines left people “magnetized” and could “interface” with 5G cellular towers, Republican lawmakers thanked her for her “enlightening” testimony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: After a Winding Journey, the Blue Jays Will Return to Canada
description: The team has been granted an exception to resume play in Toronto on July 30, with restrictions in place to help prevent coronavirus outbreaks.
content: The last time the Blue Jays played a game at Rogers Centre, their stadium in downtown Toronto, was Sept. 29, 2019. Since then, because the coronavirus pandemic led to the closing of the Canadian border, the country’s only big-league baseball team has been forced to find makeshift regular-season homes in Dunedin, Fla., its spring training site, and in Buffalo, where it displaced the franchise’s top minor league team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: ‘They’re Killing People’? Biden Isn’t Quite Right, but He’s Not Wrong.
description: Why the president says Facebook is endangering Americans.
content: It was a stunning thing to say, even if it is in many ways true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Will a Swimming Pool Help or Hurt Your Property Value?
description: You might love the idea of a backyard pool, but not everyone else does, particularly in a part of the country where summers are relatively short.
content: Q: My wife and I own a large house in Morristown, N.J., on a good-sized lot. I look out at our yard and see a perfect spot for an in-ground pool with a cabana. My wife likes the idea of a pool, too, but is concerned that it’s not a wise investment. But wouldn’t a well-designed pool add value to our property? We have the space for it, and who doesn’t like a pool?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: Overlooked No More, ‘Skipped History’ Explores Forgotten Events
description: A comedy web series hosted by a historical satirist explores overlooked ideas, people and events that continue to shape the United States.
content: “Skipped History,” a comedy web series, explores overlooked ideas, people and events that continue to shape the United States. Hosted by Ben Tumin, a historical satirist, the series makes history both accessible and funny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle, Patricia Mazzei and Giulia Heyward
title: Collapse Raises New Fears About Florida’s Shaky Insurance Market
description: Insurers were already skittish after losses from repeated hurricanes. The recent condo collapse has brought new insecurity. How long will Florida’s coast be insurable?
content: Steve Rosenthal escaped with his life when his condo building in Florida crumbled and left him homeless last month, but he still owes more than $100,000 on his mortgage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Erin Gilmer, Disability Rights Activist, Dies at 38
description: She fought for a more compassionate health care system, bringing an extensive knowledge of policy and even more extensive firsthand experience as a patient.
content: Erin Gilmer, a lawyer and disability rights activist who fought for medical privacy, lower drug prices and a more compassionate health care system as she confronted a cascade of illnesses that left her unable to work or even get out of bed for long stretches, died on July 7 in Centennial, Colo. She was 38.
source.name: The New York Times

title: There’s a Sauce for That
description: Jazz up those simple, no-cook or no-frills summer dishes with an easy green sauce or chile crisp.
content: Whatever you plan on getting up to in the kitchen this weekend, know this: We have a sauce for that. Perhaps your simple grilled chicken could use a dollop of Melissa Clark’s all-purpose green sauce (above), our most popular recipe of the week, or your fried eggs could benefit from a drizzle of Genevieve Ko’s chile crisp. Yewande Komolafe’s blistered tomato dressing is sure to brighten a summery salad or sandwich. And there’s plenty more where that came from in our collection of the best sauces New York Times Cooking has to offer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: ‘No One Is Safe’: Extreme Weather Batters the Wealthy World
description: Floods swept Germany, fires ravaged the American West and another heat wave loomed, driving home the reality that the world’s richest nations remain unprepared for the intensifying consequences of climate change.
content: Some of Europe’s richest countries lay in disarray this weekend, as raging rivers burst through their banks in Germany and Belgium, submerging towns, slamming parked cars against trees and leaving Europeans shellshocked at the intensity of the destruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Let the Games … Be Gone?
description: After bidding scandals, human rights outrages, overburdened host cities, rampant cheating, a pandemic — and, sure, thrilling competitions — has the world had enough of the Olympics?
content: In the middle of the night nearly two years ago, construction crews gathered near Senso-ji, Tokyo’s oldest Buddhist temple and a popular tourist site. The streets were empty, the air was sultry and the workers hoped it would not rain. Machines rumbled to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Steven Erlanger
title: Floods Thrust Climate Change to Center of German Campaign as Toll Mounts
description: With more than 160 dead across the region, the receding waters revealed extensive damage as well as deep political divides around how far and fast Germans should go to stem carbon use.
content: BERLIN — With the death toll surpassing 160 and rescue efforts intensifying, the once-in-a-millennium floods that ravaged Germany and much of Western Europe this week had by Saturday thrust the issue of climate change to the center of Germany’s politics and its campaign for pivotal elections this fall that will replace Chancellor Angela Merkel after 16 years in power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: The New Magazines and Journals Shaping Africa’s Literary Scene
description: Lolwe, Doek and other digital publications are helping to amplify new voices from the continent.
content: KISUMU, Kenya — While he was finishing his master’s degree in creative writing in England two years ago, Troy Onyango remembers, he lamented with his friends about how few literary outlets were devoted to Black writers, poets and photographers like them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should You Worry About Inflation? Experts Weigh In.
description: Most agree the recent spike in prices is linked to the economic recovery. When it will fade, and by how much, are less clear.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Biz Markie, Hip-Hop’s ‘Just a Friend’ Clown Prince, Dies at 57
description: An innovative yet proudly goofy rapper, he had an unlikely crossover hit with a tune that led one critic to call him (favorably) “the father of modern bad singing.”
content: Biz Markie, the innovative yet proudly goofy rapper, D.J. and producer whose self-deprecating lyrics and off-key wail on songs like “Just a Friend” earned him the nickname Clown Prince of Hip-Hop, died on Friday. He was 57.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: With Limited Access to Global Vaccine Supply, Africa’s Crisis Deepens
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 17, 2021.
content: “A vaccine delayed is a vaccine denied.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and James Glanz
title: How One of the World’s Biggest Ships Jammed the Suez Canal
description: Four months after the megaship Ever Given got stuck in the canal, neither the canal nor the shipping industry has addressed some of the most critical issues that led to the grounding.
content: CAIRO — When the Ever Given — one of the largest container ships ever built, more sideways skyscraper than boat — got stuck in the Suez Canal for six days in March, it dammed up worldwide shipping and froze nearly $10 billion in trade a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bob Morris
title: It Was Nice Not Running Into You
description: Ex-lovers, outcasts and frenemies were easy to avoid during the pandemic. Now those awkward social encounters are back.
content: The party was for the unveiling of a 1910 Grosvenor Atterbury mansion in Southampton that the developer David Walentas hopes to sell for $35 million. But the sprawling property didn’t sprawl quite enough for two guests in particular.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
title: Less vaccinated states are feeling the force of Delta’s surge in the U.S.
description: The highly contagious variant now makes up a majority of the country’s new cases, and hospitalization rates are up in states where vaccination rates are relatively low. Still, Covid-related deaths are expected to stay well below previous levels.
content: Coronavirus cases and hospitalizations in the United States remain low but are slowly rising again, driven by outbreaks in patches of the country’s center, south and west, and by tiny increases almost everywhere else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Barbara J. Litrell, 77, Dies; Publisher of Magazines for Women Who Work
description: As publisher, Ms. Litrell focused not on telling woman what to wear or how to cook, but on how to integrate into the work force.
content: Barbara J. Litrell, a publisher of women’s magazines that focused not on hair and makeup but on the contributions women made to the work force, died on July 4 at her home in Cottonwood, Ariz. She was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Democrats See Edge in Early Senate Map as Trump Casts Big Shadow
description: Early fund-raising has given Democrats cause for optimism in key states as Republicans split over how closely to align with Donald Trump’s preferences.
content: Six months into the Biden administration, Senate Democrats are expressing a cautious optimism that the party can keep control of the chamber in the 2022 midterm elections, enjoying large fund-raising hauls in marquee races as they plot to exploit Republican retirements in key battlegrounds and a divisive series of unsettled G.O.P. primaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Miami Embraces Cuba Protests: ‘I Never Thought That This Day Would Come’
description: The giddy anticipation that real change might happen on the island is tempered by wariness, especially from older exiles, that this might be one more disappointment.
content: MIAMI — The moment that Cuban exiles in Florida have so fervently ached for over the past six decades did not come when the Soviet Union fell in 1991 or when Fidel Castro died in 2016. It arrived, to their surprise, last Sunday, when Cubans on the island rushed the streets to denounce a Communist government that has left them oppressed, sick and hungry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: New evacuations are ordered in Germany, even as other residents return home after the floods.
description: Even as some Germans managed to return to their homes on Saturday amid the receding floodwaters, the danger for others had not yet passed.
content: Even as some Germans managed to return to their homes on Saturday amid the receding floodwaters, the danger for others had not yet passed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Spike Lee Accidentally Reveals Palme d’Or Winner Early: It’s ‘Titane’
description: Julia Ducournau becomes the second woman to win the top prize, after Jane Campion in 1993. The surprise reveal came at the start of a chaotic ceremony.
content: CANNES, France — The 2021 edition of the Cannes Film Festival gave its top prize, the prestigious Palme d’Or, to the French film “Titane.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Two Rods and a ‘Sixth Sense’: In Drought, Water Witches are Swamped
description: Amid California’s drought, desperate landowners and managers are turning to those who practice an ancient, disputed method for locating water.
content: CALISTOGA, Calif. — In a vineyard flanked by scorched hills and charcoal trees, Rob Thompson gripped two stainless steel rods, began rotating in a circle and counted under his breath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: John Veronis, Who Brokered Major Media Transactions, Dies at 93
description: After working as a magazine executive, he helped launch Psychology Today and played a role in Rupert Murdoch’s $3 billion purchase of the company that owned TV Guide.
content: John Veronis, an ebullient investment banker whose boutique firm specialized in major media deals, including Rupert Murdoch’s acquisition of the company that owned TV Guide, and who had earlier helped launch Psychology Today, died on June 24 at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
title: Unvaccinated States Feel Brunt of Delta-Led Covid Uptick
description: The highly contagious variant now makes up a majority of new cases, but Covid-related deaths are expected to stay well below previous peaks because of relatively higher vaccination rates across the country.
content: The highly contagious variant now makes up a majority of new cases, but Covid-related deaths are expected to stay well below previous peaks because of relatively higher vaccination rates across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weiyi Cai, Taylor Johnston, Eleanor Lutz and Tim Wallace
title: The Extent of Flooding in the Hardest-Hit Areas of Europe
description: A preliminary analysis of satellite imagery shows wide areas of flooding along rivers in western Germany and neighboring countries.
content: A preliminary analysis of satellite imagery shows wide areas of flooding along rivers in western Germany and neighboring countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ainara Tiefenthäler, Christoph Koettl and Drew Jordan
title: Satellite Images Reveal Impact of European Floods
description: Towns in multiple countries have been devastated. We used radar technology to look through the clouds at the damage below.

title: Corrections: July 17, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 17, 2021.
content: A cover article this weekend about co-working spaces misspells the surname of the chief executive of The Wing. Her name is Lauren Kassan, not Lauren Kasan.
